items.title: At 97, the Bard of Albany Still Spins Tales of Gangsters and Politicians
items.summary: William Kennedy raised money for the food pantry at his old church by reading from “Legs,” the gangster novel he began his celebrated Albany cycle with half a century ago.

items.title: Wifredo Lam: Artist-Poet of Tropical Dreams and Sorrows
items.summary: The great Cuban modernist, whose politics and Afro-Asian roots shaped his paintings and inspired generations of artists, gets a revelatory survey at MoMA.

items.title: ‘Now You See Me: Now You Don’t’ Review: Magic, the Gathering
items.summary: The Horsemen return, with some new additions, and are off to right the world’s wrongs once more.

items.title: ‘The Running Man’ Review: Glen Powell Plays for His Life
items.summary: The actor stars as an Everyman battling it out in a near-future but familiarly dystopian America in the director Edgar Wright’s new version of the Stephen King novel.

items.title: ‘Nouvelle Vague’ Review: Richard Linklater’s Ode to ‘Breathless’
items.summary: The American director moves his sights to Paris in 1959, when a young, cocky Jean-Luc Godard is hustling to make his first (now legendary) movie.

items.title: ‘The Beast in Me’ Review: On the Edge, Again, With Claire Danes
items.summary: In a Netflix thriller, the “Homeland” star plays a writer with issues and an obnoxious, possibly sociopathic new neighbor.

items.title: 5 Apps That Will Make You Love Art Galleries
items.summary: Craving an art fix but don’t know where to start? These new art influencers can help newbies and players navigate openings, events and listings.

items.title: Pioneering U.S. Street Photography, With Vienna in the Background
items.summary: Lisette Model’s candid and cruel portraits spawned an American genre. But the key to understanding her might lie in Europe, where she was born.

items.title: 5 Classical Music Albums You Can Listen to Right Now
items.summary: Meredith Monk’s “Cellular Songs,” a Kurt Weill rarity and a new take on Bach’s “Well-Tempered Clavier” are among the highlights.

items.title: ‘Archduke’ Review: Impressionable Young Men
items.summary: Rajiv Joseph’s farcical play follows the nationalists who carried out the assassination that ignited World War I.

items.title: A Company Sold Investors $1 Billion in Art. Did it Paint Too Rosy a Picture?
items.summary: Masterworks offers average investors a chance to buy individual shares in paintings often only owned by the rich, but critics say its marketing can overstate the upside of investing in its art.

items.title: Lea Michele and Her ‘Chess’ Co-Stars Know the Score
items.summary: Lea Michele, Aaron Tveit and Nicholas Christopher took a break from navigating their onstage rivalries to engage in some (mostly) friendly competition.

items.title: Claire Danes Finds New Things to Stress About in ‘The Beast in Me’
items.summary: From the teen angst of “My So-Called Life” to the midlife crisis of her new series, “The Beast in Me,” the actor has embodied the stresses of each stage of life.

items.title: Sofia Coppola Honored at MoMA Benefit With Elle Fanning, Bill Murray and David Letterman
items.summary: The Museum of Modern Art’s annual film gala honored the writer and director, attracting a crowd that included Olivia Wilde, Bill Murray and David Letterman.

items.title: ‘Viridiana’ Was Luis Buñuel’s Revenge
items.summary: The 1961 film, which was banned in Spain, has been restored and revived in a limited run at Film Forum.

items.title: ‘The Things You Kill’ Review: A Tragedy Turns Surreal
items.summary: A slippery Turkish-language feature takes its time revealing its mysteries.

items.title: ‘Rebuilding’ Review: When Life Bucks You Off
items.summary: In this gentle western, Josh O’Connor plays a cowboy who’s lost his ranch and sense of self to a wildfire.

items.title: ‘Keeper’ Review: You Can Get In, but You Can’t Get Out
items.summary: This entertainingly loopy horror movie from Osgood Perkins is a cabin-in-the-woods chiller with a girl power spin.

items.title: ‘King Ivory’ Review: Oklahoma Turns Gangland
items.summary: A starry action-thriller with noble intentions fumbles the fentanyl epidemic.

items.title: ‘The Carpenter’s Son’ Review: The First Temptation of Christ?
items.summary: In this horror movie drawn from the Apocrypha, a teen Jesus is both troubled and troubling to his parents. Then along comes a stranger with a serpent.

items.title: ‘Bunny’ Review: Doing the Right Thing
items.summary: Ben Jacobson’s caper set in an East Village tenement hinges on the camaraderie of neighbors and teems with energy.

items.title: ‘Being Eddie’ Review: Eddie Murphy Looks Back
items.summary: A self-aware and soft-spoken Eddie Murphy plays docent to his own career in a new documentary.

items.title: ‘Arco’ Review: A Technicolor Apocalypse
items.summary: A boy empowered by a time-traveling cape crash-lands in 2075 in this inventive animated film that wrestles with the effects of climate change and technology.

items.title: Late Night Pops Off on Trump Popping Up in Epstein Email Thread
items.summary: Josh Johnson said that Jeffrey Epstein’s references to President Trump might not mean much: “Maybe the email was about how Trump never comes to his sex parties — rude.”

items.title: Watch Lesley Manville and Mark Strong of Broadway’s ‘Oedipus’ Go Head-to-Head
items.summary: As the show opens in New York, its stars took their places amid the desks of T Magazine to deliver a pivotal scene.

items.title: Sally Kirkland, Scene-Stealing Actress, Dies at 84
items.summary: She received an Oscar nomination for the 1987 film “Anna” but spent much of her prolific career as a go-to supporting actress in movies like “The Sting” and “JFK.”

items.title: Sting to Bring ‘The Last Ship’ to the Met Opera
items.summary: After his musical “The Last Ship” failed on Broadway, Sting is bringing a revised version to the Met as the house looks for new sources of revenue.

items.title: Hollywood Bowl Names Its Stage for John Williams
items.summary: The celebrated venue dedicated its stage to the composer for “Star Wars,” “Jurassic Park” and other blockbusters, a first in the bowl’s 103 years.

items.title: Lucas Museum of Narrative Art in Los Angeles Sets 2026 Opening Date
items.summary: The 300,000-square-foot building will open Sept. 22 and showcase comic art, illustrations and more across 35 galleries. It began construction in 2018 but faced multiple delays.

items.title: Hal Sirowitz, Poet Who Mined His Mother’s Worry With Wit, Dies at 76
items.summary: He wrote of his suffocating relationship with his mother to create mordant reminiscences and became a standout at poetry slams in New York.

items.title: Premieres at the Paul Taylor Dance Company Lose the Taylor Thread
items.summary: As part of its Lincoln Center season, the company presented works by Lauren Lovette, Robert Battle and Hope Boykin.

items.title: Review: Rennie Harris’s Jam Session of American Street Dance
items.summary: At the Joyce Theater, “American Street Dancer” offers a history lesson in the form of a family’s house party.

items.title: Getting Into the Arena as ‘The Hunger Games’ Goes Live
items.summary: At a specially built theater, the hit book and movie franchise has been transformed into a theatrical experience, with real fire and flying arrows.

items.title: In ‘The Seduction,’ a ‘Dangerous Liaisons’ for This Moment
items.summary: The French-language series from HBO focuses on the young Marquise de Merteuil — and on love, broken promises and manipulation.

items.title: ‘The Baker’s Wife’ Review: Ariana DeBose Returns to New York Stage
items.summary: The Oscar winner takes on a lovely yet tricky role in a Stephen Schwartz musical that never made it to Broadway back in 1976.

items.title: College Romance Books That Will Make You Swoon
items.summary: The explosive potential of those years makes every emotion more intense — and a perfect combo for rich storytelling.

items.title: Does This $1 Billion Art Collection Paint Too Rosy a Picture?
items.summary: “No art investing experience? No problem,” the website of Masterworks announces. Zachary Small, a New York Times reporter covering the art world, explains why some experts see a problem.

items.title: Josh Johnson Isn’t Sold on Trump’s 50-Year Mortgage Plan
items.summary: “This seems like a bad idea. And if Black people could get loans, I’d be worried,” Johnson said on “The Daily Show.”

items.title: 3 Bob Ross Paintings Sell for $600,000 to Support Public Broadcasters
items.summary: The landscapes by the television host were sold as part of a campaign to help public television stations weather federal funding cuts.

items.title: Cleto Escobedo III, Jimmy Kimmel’s Bandleader, Dies at 59
items.summary: Mr. Kimmel said that he and Mr. Escobedo, who led Cleto and the Cletones on “Jimmy Kimmel Live!,” had been “inseparable since I was 9 years old.”

items.title: Pope Leo Shares His Favorite Movies Ahead of Vatican Event
items.summary: The list leans heavily on uplifting classics.

items.title: A Latin Grammys Primer in 11 Songs
items.summary: Prepare for the big show on Thursday with tracks by nominated artists: Karol G, Sued Nunes, Ivan Cornejo and more.

items.title: Trump Cuts and Orders Have Broad Impact on American Museums, Report Finds
items.summary: A survey of museum directors reveals the impact of federal cutbacks: reduced arts programs for rural areas, students and people who are elderly or disabled.

items.title: Veterans Day TV: Divergent Stories From Forever Wars
items.summary: “The Warfighters: Battle Stories” and “In Waves and Wars” explore veterans’ experiences from radically different points of view.

items.title: Bookstore Food Drives Help Food Stamp Recipients
items.summary: During the government shutdown, booksellers are collecting food for Americans who receive federal aid to buy groceries.

items.title: ‘Squid Game’ Actor’s Sexual Misconduct Conviction Is Overturned
items.summary: Oh Young-soo played a contestant in the first season of the Netflix drama. Prosecutors have a week to appeal to the country’s Supreme Court.

items.title: In This Rarely Seen Tchaikovsky Opera, Joan of Arc Speaks for Herself
items.summary: The composer had grand hopes that “The Maid of Orleans,” with its battle scenes, rousing choruses and fiery finale, would be the making of him. It didn’t work out that way.

items.title: Huang Ruo’s ‘The Monkey King’: A Shape-Shifting Hero for a Third Culture Opera
items.summary: Huang Ruo’s “The Monkey King” at San Francisco Opera transforms a classic Chinese tale into a reflection on identity, enlightenment and the creativity sparked when cultures entwine.

items.title: Ruth Childs Steps Out of a Giant Shadow (Her Aunt, Lucinda Childs’s)
items.summary: Ruth Childs, the niece of the renowned choreographer Lucinda Childs, got over being intimidated by her aunt’s achievements. Now, she debuts her own work in New York.

items.title: How Brawling Dramas Take the Fight to the Oscars
items.summary: With their slow-mo punch sequences and actors’ body transformations, pugilistic films from “Rocky” to “Christy” have aimed for the academy’s approval.

items.title: Sarah Jessica Parker Describes Her Year as a Booker Prize Judge
items.summary: The actor had to read so many books (153) she bowed out of most family activities. Still, she said, collaborating to pick a winner was worth the sacrifice.

items.title: The Volunteer Buglers Giving 24-Note Salutes
items.summary: Thousands of musicians — civilians, veterans, teenagers, retirees — are playing taps at military funerals in a rebuke of technology.

items.title: Late Night Is Disappointed in Democrats Over Shutdown Deal
items.summary: “Our long national nightmare is different,” Stephen Colbert said after some Democratic senators voted with Republicans to end the government shutdown.

items.title: Tatsuya Nakadai, Japanese Star Known for ‘Ran’ and Other Classics, Dies at 92
items.summary: He was a fixture of postwar Japanese cinema, appearing in films by Akira Kurosawa and other leading directors of that era.

items.title: ‘Richard II’ Review: Michael Urie Is a Cynical, Comic Monarch
items.summary: The inventive comic actor delivers a commanding performance in Shakespeare’s portrait of feckless leadership in a sleek Off Broadway adaptation.

items.title: Sean ‘Diddy’ Combs Could Trim Prison Sentence With Drug Rehab Program
items.summary: A spokesman for the fallen music mogul, who is serving a four-year sentence for prostitution-related offenses at the Fort Dix prison complex in New Jersey, said he has been accepted to the program.

items.title: 2025 Booker Prize Goes to David Szalay’s ‘Flesh’
items.summary: The rags-to-riches tale had already made fans of Zadie Smith and Dua Lipa. Roddy Doyle, who chaired the judging panel, called the book “singular” and “extraordinary.”

items.title: Honoring a Sassy, Hammer-Wielding Nun
items.summary: The nun known as Mother Carmen is the first female saint from Venezuela. Her portrait and reliquary give some hints as to why.

items.title: As Art Deco Turns 100, a Paris Museum Celebrates
items.summary: A centenary celebration of Art Deco style recalls an age of opulence.

items.title: Review: Hildegard of Bingen’s Extraordinary Life, on Operatic Scale
items.summary: Sarah Kirkland Snider’s gorgeously mesmerizing first opera has both focus and a thematically expansive view of a moment in medieval history.
